newsitem.title: USA: Austin, Tx., restores power after substation fire.
newsitem.headline: Austin, Tx., restores power after substation fire.

text.p: The city of Austin, Texas restored service Tuesday to all 30,000 customers whose power was disrupted when a fire broke out at a downtown substation Monday afternoon, spokespeople for the city said.
"The outages are taken care of. All the power has been restored," said Carlos Cardova, a city government spokesman.
About 10 percent of 300,000 customers, or a third of the downtown population served by the Austin Electric Utility Department, lost power for several hours.

Preliminary findings indicated an internal fault inside a substation transformer which about 1600 CST ignited the mineral oil used to cool the transformer, said Cathy Kirwin, a spokeswoman for electric department.
"We have some service now from the station," she added.
The transformer augments voltage from a 69 kilovolt (KV) cable for a 130 KV line. The energy on the 69 KV cable comes from several generation stations within Austin.
The substation is in the switchyard of the 120 megawatt (MW) Seaholm power plant, which is now deactivated.
Some of the electricity deliveries that usually feed into the Seaholm substation have been re-routed to surrounding facilities, Kirwin said.
Kirwin said it would take less than 30 days to clean up the substation, but much longer to replace and install a new transformer.
"The fire is out at this time, but there was a small flare up at 0445-0500 CST," said Cathy Brandewie, a spokeswoman for the city's fire department.
